text: Wonderful, delicious food.  The shrimp curry was sensational ... incredible, complex flavor.  The vegetables were perfectly prepared and the beef dish was spectacular as well.  Love, love this place.
le sourire en entrant, en parlant et en mangeant !!! les crevettes au lait de coco et curry sont delicieuses...
The food here was delicious! The atmosphere was great. They had vegetarian menu options. We're so happy to have this place in the neighborhood.

Je l'avais vu peu de temps après son ouverture et j'y suis finalement allée. On mange très bien, les portions sont généreuses, j'ai dû rapporter les restes et j'ai eu un deuxième repas! La nourriture est savoureuse. L'ambiance est agréable. Je vais y retourner, c'est certain. Longue vie.

I went here the other day with my boyfriend cause he was really craving Caribbean style food and I was pleasantly surprised it was really good and the price that they were selling was pretty good as well I ended up getting some Maringo oil because of Saul of a few products in the store and this oil is probably the best oil I've ever used in my life for skin and that on top of the food I will definitely go back!!! Even though it's not my culture anything it was like having a home cooked meal which is rare to find a restaurant around here in Montreal!

Such a lovely neighbourhood spot!  My partner and I popped in for a rare weekday kid free lunch, and this was exactly what we were looking for: reasonably priced delicious food in a relaxing atmosphere.  The place is tiny but I wouldn't call it a whole in the wall.  Bright and spotless, the restaurant doubles as a little grocery for Caribbean items.  Spices, books, packaged foods, all kinds of neat stuff.  The eating area in the front has two tables, a sofa and a window counter that would be perfect for a solo lunch.  When we visited, perhaps because it was lunch right before the holidays, there wasn't much choice, but what we sampled was great!  My partner had a spicy chicken sandwich, and I had a beef stew.  Well spiced, not too heavy, just right!

je veux vraiment aimer ce petit resto de quartier charmant. selon moi, la bouffe est vraiment trop sec et les portions ne sont pas assez grands pour le prix (12 à 15 $).  I've been here twice since it's opened, and both times i thought the food was too dry and the portions were too small for the price (we're talking a chicken thigh, lots of rice and beans, salad and plantains -- all too dry -- for $12). we always went later in the evening, so maybe that's why... but that also shouldn't be an issue no matter when you go.   maybe they are still fine-tuning; it's still fairly new after all.    but i won't give up on this place... third times' the charm after all, right?

One of my friends had recommended this place to me when it opened because having a Guadeloupean mom, she wanted to have my opinion on their menu.  Since I went there one afternoon, I did not order a dish but rather had coffee with accras of cod and an Ordinaire (an anise soda very popular in the French West Indies). The accras were excellent and similar to those that my mom cook (Understand: the spices were not diminished, which is a plus for me).   Also, I really appreciated the friendly service of the staff adorned with the traditional Caribbean coiffe, plus they have an excellent selection of delicatessen products from Martinique, Guadeloupe, and Haiti. I will, of course, have to go back and try the rest of the menu.

Cuisine très goûteuse, portions adéquates, voyage des papilles garanti. J'ai essayé le poulet, le porc avec les deux sortes de riz, les accras et tout était très bien réussi. Le service était rapide (ce sont pour la plupart des mijotés). Les prix sont également plus que raisonnable, ce qui est parfois rare pour l'avenue du Mont-Royal.   Si je n'avais qu'un seul point négatif, ce serait plutôt au niveau des plats de take-out, qui par grande chaleur et avec la condensation des plats se deconstruisent rapidement.   Gardez en tête qu'il n'y a pas beaucoup de places assises.
Bon griot avec riz collé et bananes pesées, bel endroit, style boutique resto avec une douzaine de places assises.

This little resto is located on the east end of the Plateau and offers a daily menu of Caribbean eats including full plates, sandwiches and entrees, as well as fresh juices. The seating is very limited and this spot is popular for lunch so I always end up grabbing my lunch to go. Today was my second visit and I had the griot plate;. The plate comes with the fried pork which was tender and deliciously seasoned, a small salad with a fantastic dressing, plantains that are always fresh and warm, as well as a generous portion of flavourful rice with beans. I am hooked and brought my haïtien friend along who totally approved of the calalou beef. We got to share the rum cake for dessert, and I swear this  had to be the more flavourful and moist rum cake I've ever had the pleasure of tasting!   The only reason I've given four stars is because of the service; although the staff is super friendly and personable, there is always one person on cash and serving so the wait can be long during lunch rush.   You can also pick up a few native delicacies and drinks as this spot also serves as a small market offering jars, cans, and bottles of Caribbean goods.

We were visiting Montreal last week and a friend of ours mentioned Aux Iles à Sucre in the Plateau Mont-Royal which offered dishes from the islands that we love. They had a great choice of meat, chicken, fish and vegetarian dishes accompanied with rice, fried plantains and salad. They also have different kind of pates. With our family we had the meat and chicken dishes which tasted great and we even ordered plantains and rice to take out so we can have it as a snack the next day at the hotel:-)   The atmosphere is great with unique shopping items offered from Guadeloupe, Martinique, Dominique and Haiti. Naturally the cooking is also influenced by these islands.   The decor is great, the food can be eaten on the premises or taken out. There are great deserts and juices made on the premises. They also offer a mini-market for fresh fruits and vegetables, and locally made chocolates.

Ouvert depuis deux semaines seulement, c'est déjà un coup de coeur pour plusieurs résidents du coin.  Et on comprend pourquoi!   On vous sert ici une bonne nourriture créole, et ce avec un sourire tout caribéen.  Ce sont donc généralement des viandes mijotées, façon ragoût, délicieusement relevées par un mélange d'épices et de condiments qui ne ressemblent à rien d'autre qu'à elles-mêmes, sinon peut-être au paradis (jusqu'à présent, je suis fan de la chèvre, mais le porc est absolument délicieux lui aussi), accompagné d'un riz (je ne sais pas ce qu'il mettent de dedans, mais c'est absolument délicieux!), d'une salade (OK) et d'une tranche de plantain.  Le repas complet vous coûte 12$, une misère compte tenu de la qualité et des saveurs (sans parler du quartier...).  Bien que l'endroit soit assez coquet, il s'agit davantage d'un service de traiteur que d'un véritable restaurant.  Une moitié du petit local sert d'épicerie créole, ne laissant, pour manger, que la place pour une dizaine de personnes.  On vous sert d'ailleurs dans un cabaret de cafétéria, qui jure plutôt avec les jolies tables en bois et le décors immaculé.    Bien que personnellement j'aime bien manger sur place, l'option de prendre pour emporter devient très avantageuse si on est un peu nombreux (3 ou plus).

J'aime la decoration et la propeté de la place, gout des caraibes mmmmm , bon service et boutique sur place pour qq produits importés. Grand fenestration ce qui est toujours apprecié. Petite terrasse dispo.
